review_title: Need a lot of patience for teaching
pros: One of few places that offer full-time teaching positions, without demanding research activity
cons: Computer science lectures leave students disengaged, and tutorial attendance is low. Coursework and deadlines do not integrate well with taught material, causing poor performance. Administrative load is large and a bit haphazard, causing staff a lot of hassle and also leading to disengagement. Unnecessary bureaucracy (e.g. IT support and provisioning, departmental procedures) is frustrating. Overall, it may be tolerable but expect to push back against institutional failings, and play the long game to find your niche.

pros: Not much to report - perhaps the ability to work from home 2 days a week? Though this may change - nothing guaranteed.
cons: the dean summarised it perfectly - City has a lot of staff who leave in less than 2 years, and many who have been around for 15+ years - not much in between. A lot of set systems and dinasours who are making decisions that they are not qualified to make. I would avoid.

review_title: Hit or miss but can be a great experience
pros: Good benefits and stratified organisation which means you are empowered to focus on the tasks specific to your role. You don't have to do your job and that of those in five other teams. Local management really cares, especially at the School of Health & Psychological Sciences. Good work/life balance. Hybrid working and great OH department.
cons: Senior central leadership seem to operate on their own planet so their objectives can feel very distant to one's day-to-day tasks, even after years in the organisation. Teams can be hit or miss in terms of how cohesive and organised they are so ask good questions at interview stage.

review_title: Conformist against its own best interest
pros: When I started working at City, it was a lovely place. A small university in the red-bricked landscape of Islington; a place with a personal touch where things could get done face-to-face. The personable working environment has mostly gone, due to the ridiculous bid to climb up the rankings in the space of a few years. However, the location in East London is still really nice, and something I miss.
cons: After a failed bid to join the University of London with a previous VC, the new 'strategic plan' became to try and climb up the rankings by injecting loads of money in the University. Per se, this wasn't a bad idea: many new and talented lecturers were hired, a proper doctoral community started springing up. However, the sheer breakneck pace of change has been unsustainable. Many new degrees have been launched and the hiring, however conspicuous, hasn't kept up, with teaching increasingly given out to contract lecturers or PhDs. Moreover, the research environment, while on the one hand foraged with much financial investment, has also been a paramount example of the negativity of REF politics. The strategising around research submissions has left many people at the margins, breeding frustration and resentment. Outside of those academics who are cozy with management, the place is a kettle waiting to burst.

pros: This is a really positive workplace, I enjoyed working there immensely. Great staff, good students, and it's in a fantastic location with good access to transport links and local amenities.
cons: Overall I have no negative comments, this is a lovely University to work for.

pros: Competitive amongst Higher Education salaries. Investment on estates means better offices. Location is great for after work and lunch appointments. Very good transport links. Projects going on for equality.
cons: There are constant restructures/ reviews/  negotiations etc on what seems like an 18 month cycle. Bureaucracy is at it;s highest at the moment too.
